headline: WRTA seeks fed grant to fund improvements
author: Sean Barron
sentences: U.S. Rep. Tim Ryan, D-Howland, and the U.S. Department of Transportation recently announced the money would be available, as part of President Joe Biden’s bipartisan Infrastructure law, to modernize bus fleets and facilities throughout Ohio and nationwide.

Money also will be available to offer financial assistance to build bus facilities, according to the FTAás website, www.transit.dot.gov
So far, four such projects across Ohio have been awarded funds from the grant, the website also shows.

The move promises to support good paying jobs, help reduce carbon emissions that will result in cleaner air and healthier communities and lead to more efficient transportation, according to the U.S. Federal Transit Administration.
In addition, the funds will be used to assist local transit agencies in buying or leasing U.S.-built low- or no-emission vehicles with advanced technologies and rehabilitating current buses and vans.
YOUNGSTOWN — The Western Reserve Transit Authority has applied for $5 million of a $1.47 billion competitive federal grant to fund a variety of upgrades and improvements to its bus garage.
“We don’t have a need to replace our buses (with the money), but we want to rehabilitate our bus barn,” Dean Harris, WRTA’s executive director, said last week.
